ReviewList.Text: Original book had drawings by the author that illustrated the text.  This Kindle version does not have the drawings, and the story loses a lot because of that.

An amazing book that really takes you out of your own dimension and leaves you wondering about the others that may lie above! If you are really interested in this sort of thinking you can make it as long, and as short of a read as you would like to indulge yourself. I took my time and I think it really paid off by the end, a really amazing book from a time before CGI and graphics leaving yourself with your mind, Abbott's imagination, and a square.

It is difficult to imagine fourth spatial dimension, much less 11 that string theory suggests, but just because we cannot even conceive the idea doesn't mean it is not possible. After all, a being in flatland finds our three dimensional world as unfathomable as we find multidimensional world. Flatland is a short and simple read but opens mind to fantasy world of no dimension (pointland), one dimension (lineland) and two dimensions (flatland). Author's imaginations conjure up social hierarchy, ruling structure, culture and history of a fictional world forcing the reader to stretch his imaginations. An quick enjoyable stimulating read that will leave you smiling and thinking in the end.

This book had the potential to be interesting had it not been for the ambiguous writing. The writing style was difficult to get through. The writer tended to use many run on sentences which made it difficult to follow the thoughts he was trying to convey. It also seemed like he was trying to write along the lines of Shakespeare, but the subject material did not lend creedence to this style. The writing style was also inconsistent. It seemed like someone else wrote the last two sections of the book. This was also the most smooth flowing portion of the book. The enjoyable part of the book was using your imagination to see the different dimensional worlds that were visited in the book.

It is hard to imagine such an intense combination of science, creativity and spirituality all rolled into one. The book is not an easy read but definitely a fascinating one. The creation and description of a two dimensional society in such great detail leaves one full of amazement. The idea of introducing an additional dimension, incomprehensible to people of two dimensional world as an indicator of our own limitations in realizing and recognizing what lies beyond or within our world is very touching. The "Upward not northward" notion, that the Square so tried to explain and preach could perhaps best be translated to "inwards not outwards" for us in our own world.

I have used some of the concepts in this book to illustrate the nature of God as revealed in the Christian Bible, since in the Bible God is revealed as infintie and eternal--concepts beyond our 3 dimensional framework of existence. However, I found it a bit funny that Amazon asked me to evaluate whether the characters in the book were only one-dimensional, developed, or complex! Indeed, as a book about dimensional creatures, it included both one, two and three dimensional creatures and characters. However, the reader is 'asked' to sympathize with the most developed character of all--the two dimensional one!

The old style is evident, perhaps mostly in the copious amounts of exposition the author delivers. I understand that sci-fi was still a nascent genre at the time, and many have since learned to more gracefully introduce their worlds to the reader. However this book is still quite thought-provoking in many ways and a fairly gripping read once the world is established.
This book is great if you love classic fiction and great language. However if you wish to be entertained this is not the book for you.
What's not to love?  This is a timeless classic of duo-dimensional proportions.  Make it a part of your digital library or else...

For those who would like to get a better appreciation for why it is difficult to imagine four and higher dimensions for us 3D creatures, it is best to try and see how 3D can be difficult for 2D creatures to comprehend and this story gives you a glimpse into a 2D world. And if there are entities in higher dimensions than ours how trivial our world must look to them..  great read.
Definitely recommend this book.  Interesting story with an intro to planar, spatial, and higher order geometries hidden within.  Definitely suggest this book for everyone.
I experienced Flatland when I was in high school. We even watched the movie. Reading this again has brought back wonderful memories. It is a psychological tale set in a 2-dimensional world.

I had a very hard time with the old fashioned style of language in this book. The first two thirds of the book were very hard to get through. It was hard to understand, as well as boring. It took the first two thirds to set up the background of the story. Once I made it to where the story actually started, it was easier to read. The language was still very old fashioned, but the story helped to get past it. All in all, I don't think I would recommend this book.
